RPKI Manifest Number Handling RPKI Repository Handling Updates
draft-harrison-sidrops-manifest-numbers-01 draft-harrison-sidrops-manifest-numbers-02
Abstract Abstract
The Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) makes use of signed The Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) makes use of
objects called manifests. A manifest lists each file that a repositories for the publication of certificates and other objects.
publisher intends to include within an RPKI repository, and can be At a minimum, each repository contains a Certificate Revocation List
used to detect certain forms of attack against a repository. (CRL) for the publishing Certification Authority (CA), as well as a
Manifests include a "manifest number" (manifestNumber), which the signed object called a manifest that lists each file that a publisher
publisher must increment whenever it issues a new manifest, and intends to include within the repository. In certain scenarios, the
Relying Parties (RPs) are required to verify that a newly-retrieved CRL and/or the manifest may contain data that leads Relying Parties
manifest for a given Certification Authority (CA) has a higher (RPs) to treat the repository as being permanently unusable. This
manifestNumber than the previously-validated manifest. However, the document updates the previous requirements in this space such that
manifestNumber field is 20 octets in length (i.e. not unbounded), and CAs are able to recover from these scenarios.
no behaviour is specified for when a manifestNumber reaches the
largest possible value. This document specifies publisher and RP
behaviour for this scenario.

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
The Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) [RFC6480] makes use of The Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) [RFC6480] makes use of
signed objects [RFC6488] called manifests [RFC9286]. A manifest repositories [RFC6481] for the publication of certificates and other
lists each file that a publisher intends to include within an RPKI objects. At a minimum, each repository contains a Certificate
repository [RFC6481], and can be used to detect certain forms of Revocation List (CRL) [RFC6487] for the publishing Certification
attack against a repository. Manifests include a "manifest number" Authority (CA), as well as a signed object called a manifest
(manifestNumber), which the publisher must increment whenever it [RFC9286] that lists each file that a publisher intends to include
issues a new manifest, and Relying Parties (RPs) are required to within the repository. In certain scenarios, the CRL and/or the
verify that a newly-retrieved manifest for a given Certification manifest may contain data that leads clients to treat the repository
Authority (CA) has a higher manifestNumber than the previously- as being permanently unusable.
validated manifest (see section 4.2.1 of [RFC9286]).
For example, manifests include a "manifest number" (manifestNumber),
which the publisher must increment whenever it issues a new manifest,
and Relying Parties (RPs) are required to verify that a newly-
retrieved manifest for a given Certification Authority (CA) has a
higher manifestNumber than the previously-validated manifest (see
section 4.2.1 of [RFC9286]).
However, the manifestNumber field is 20 octets in length (i.e. not However, the manifestNumber field is 20 octets in length (i.e. not
unbounded), and no behaviour is specified for when a manifestNumber unbounded), and no behaviour is specified for when a manifestNumber
reaches the largest possible value, which means that a publisher can reaches the largest possible value (2^159-1), which means that a
no longer make use of a given CA certificate when that value is publisher can no longer make use of a given CA certificate when that
reached. (For the purposes of [RFC9286], a "CA" is represented by a value is reached. (For the purposes of [RFC9286], a "CA" is
CA certificate with a stable location and a stable private key. represented by a CA certificate with a stable location and a stable
Reissuing a CA certificate with changed resources or a changed expiry private key. Reissuing a CA certificate with changed resources or a
date does not change the identity of the CA such that the stored changed expiry date does not change the identity of the CA such that
manifestNumber for the CA is reset, for example.) the stored manifestNumber for the CA is reset, for example.)
While it is practically impossible for a publisher to reach the While it is practically impossible for a publisher to reach the
largest possible value under normal operating conditions (it would largest possible value under normal operating conditions (it would
require that the publisher issue one manifest per second for require that the publisher issue one manifest per second for
46,343,912,903,694,283,301,740 quintillion years), there is a chance 46,343,912,903,694,283,301,740 quintillion years), there is a chance
that it could be reached due to bugs in the issuance or publication that it could be reached due to bugs in the issuance or publication

"SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this
document are to be interpreted as described in [RFC2119] [RFC8174]. document are to be interpreted as described in [RFC2119] [RFC8174].
2. Manifest Number Handling 2. Manifest Number Handling
For a given CA, an RP MUST NOT reject a new manifest issued by that For a given CA, an RP MUST NOT reject a new manifest issued by that
CA on the grounds of it not having a higher manifestNumber than a CA on the grounds of it not having a higher manifestNumber than a
previously validated manifest if the new manifest has a different previously-validated manifest if the new manifest has a different
filename from that of the previously validated manifest. In other filename from that of the previously-validated manifest. In other
words, an RP MUST reset its stored manifestNumber for a given CA if words, an RP MUST reset its stored manifestNumber for a given CA if
the CA changes the filename of its manifest. the CA changes the filename of its manifest.
With this behaviour, it is possible for a CA to be configured such With this behaviour, it is possible for a CA to be configured such
that any time it issues a new manifest, it uses a new filename for that any time it issues a new manifest, it uses a new filename for
that manifest. If a CA were configured in this way, the that manifest. If a CA were configured in this way, the
manifestNumber validation set out in section 4.2.1 of [RFC9286] would manifestNumber validation set out in section 4.2.1 of [RFC9286] would
have no purpose. To avoid this outcome, CAs SHOULD NOT use new have no purpose. To avoid this outcome, CAs SHOULD NOT use new
filenames for manifests except in situations where it is necessary to filenames for manifests except in situations where it is necessary to
ensure the ongoing validity of the CA or its repository. Similarly, ensure the ongoing validity of the CA or its repository. Similarly,
RP software SHOULD alert its operators when a manifest filename RP software SHOULD alert its operators when a manifest filename
changes for a given CA. changes for a given CA.
Note that this approach is different from that described in To avoid certain forms of replay attack, the RP MUST verify that the
Section 3.2.1 of [RFC8488]. URI in the accessLocation in one of the id-ad-signedObject
accessMethods in the manifest's Subject Information (SIA) extension
exactly matches the URI presented in the RPKI Repository Delta
Protocol (RRDP) [RFC8182] "publish" element or the path presented by
remote rsync servers.
3. Operational Considerations Section 2.2 of [RFC6481] contains non-normative guidance for the
naming of manifest files in repositories. While a CA that supports
the behaviour described in this section cannot preserve the exact
filename suggested by that text (per section 2.1 of [RFC4387]), the
CA SHOULD still ensure that the filename is a value derived from the
public key of the CA, per the more general guidance in that section.
Note that the approach set out in this section is different from that
described in Section 3.2.1 of [RFC8488].
3. CRL Number Handling
Section 5 of [RFC6487] states that "[w]here two or more CRLs are
issued by the same CA, the CRL with the highest value of the 'CRL
Number' field supersedes all other CRLs issued by this CA". This
document updates that guidance such that where an RP retrieves a
repository, and the CRL in the repository has a different filename
from that of the previously-validated CRL, the newly-retrieved CRL
supersedes any previously-validated CRL.
With this behaviour, it is possible for a CA to be configured such
that any time it issues a new CRL, it uses a new filename for that
CRL. If a CA were configured in this way, the guidance from
[RFC6487] would have no purpose. To avoid this outcome, CAs SHOULD
NOT use new filenames for CRLs except in situations where it is
necessary to ensure the ongoing validity of the CA or its repository.
Similarly, RP software SHOULD alert its operators when a CRL filename
changes for a given CA.
Section 2.2 of [RFC6481] contains non-normative guidance for the
naming of CRLs in repositories. While a CA that supports the
behaviour described in this section cannot preserve the exact
filename suggested by that text (per section 2.1 of [RFC4387]), the
CA SHOULD still ensure that the filename is a value derived from the
public key of the CA, per the more general guidance in that section.
4. General Repository Handling
The previous sections contain specific updates to address potential
permanent invalidity scenarios. Notwithstanding the above, RPs that
encounter other permanent invalidity scenarios SHOULD consider how
those can be addressed such that the scenario does not require the
relevant CA or TA to perform a key rollover operation. For example,
in the event that an RP recognises that a permanent invalidity
scenario has occurred, the RP could alert the operator and provide an
option to the operator to stop relying on cached data for the
affected repository, so that the CA can rectify the problem.
5. Operational Considerations
CA software may opt to support this functionality in various ways. CA software may opt to support this functionality in various ways.
For example, it could change the manifest filename when the For example, it could change the manifest filename when the
manifestNumber reaches a certain threshold, or it could alert the manifestNumber reaches a certain threshold, or it could alert the
operator in this scenario and request confirmation that the filename operator in this scenario and request confirmation that the filename
should be changed. should be changed.

Appendix A. Serial Number Arithmetic Appendix A. Serial Number Arithmetic
Serial number arithmetic [RFC1982] is an approach that has been used Serial number arithmetic [RFC1982] is an approach that has been used
in the DNS context (among others) to permit the indefinite use of a in the DNS context (among others) to permit the indefinite use of a
finite number space. At least in theory, it would be possible to use finite number space. At least in theory, it would be possible to use
a similar approach with the manifestNumber field as well. a similar approach with the manifestNumber and CRLNumber fields as
well.
However, unlike the corresponding DNS context with SOA resource However, unlike the corresponding DNS context with SOA resource
records, an RPKI CA does not have visibility into or control over records, an RPKI CA does not have visibility into or control over
RPKI RPs generally. This means that it is not possible to select RPKI RPs generally. This means that it is not possible to select
updated manifestNumber values or to manage the relevant state updated manifestNumber/CRLNumber values or to manage the relevant
transitions so as to definitively ensure that all RPs will have valid state transitions so as to definitively ensure that all RPs will have
state at the end of the process. The approach proposed in Section 2 valid state at the end of the process. The approach proposed in
does not have this problem. Section 2 does not have this problem.
Appendix B. Walkthrough of the rpki-client implementation Appendix B. Manifest thisUpdate
The thisUpdate field in the manifest object is of type
GeneralizedTime, defined in section 4.1.2.5.2 of [RFC5280]. This
type has a maximum value of 99991231235959Z (i.e. 31 December 9999
23:59:59 GMT). Section 4.2.1 of [RFC9286] requires that "[e]ach RP
MUST verify that this field value is greater (more recent) than the
most recent manifest it has validated", so it would appear to be
subject to the same problem as for manifest and CRL numbers.
However, during validation, if the RP detects that the current time
is not between the manifest thisUpdate and nextUpdate values, the RP
must treat the fetch as a failed fetch. Therefore, the RP will not
cache a manifest with a current date far in the future, and the CA
can rectify the problem here by reissuing the relevant manifest with
the correct date.
Appendix C. CRL thisUpdate
The thisUpdate field in a CRL may be encoded using either the UTCTime
type or the GeneralizedTime type, with UTCTime being used for dates
with a year value up to 2049, and GeneralizedTime being used for
dates with a year value of 2050 or greater. As with the
corresponding manifest field, it is possible to issue a CRL with a
thisUpdate value corresponding to 31 December 9999 23:59:59 GMT.
However, there are no requirements in previous specifications with
respect to the thisUpdate and nextUpdate fields in a CRL, save that
those should coincide with the corresponding manifest values (section
4.4 of [RFC9286]).
Appendix D. Walkthrough of the rpki-client implementation
This section describes the [rpki-client] implementation with regard This section describes the [rpki-client] implementation with regard
to handling manifest numbers. The process is composed of multiple to handling manifest numbers. The process is composed of multiple
stages: stages:
1. Fetching the manifests and acquiring referenced files 1. Fetching the manifests and acquiring referenced files
2. Preprocessing of the manifests 2. Preprocessing of the manifests
3. Selecting the first candidate manifest 3. Selecting the first candidate manifest
4. Matching file names and hashes 4. Matching file names and hashes
5. Optionally selecting the second candidate manifest 5. Optionally selecting the second candidate manifest
B.1. Stage: Fetching the Manifests and Acquiring Referenced Files D.1. Stage: Fetching the Manifests and Acquiring Referenced Files
The RP follows _rpkiNotify_ or _caRepository_ pointers in the The RP follows _rpkiNotify_ or _caRepository_ pointers in the
_SubjectInfoAccess_ extension of valid CA certificates to queue up _SubjectInfoAccess_ extension of valid CA certificates to queue up
synchronization tasks. synchronization tasks.
At the end of this stage the RP has zero, one, or two manifests for a At the end of this stage the RP has zero, one, or two manifests for a
given _caRepository_. Depending on the validation status, the RP given _caRepository_. Depending on the validation status, the RP
stores files into two locations: _DIR_VALID_ or _DIR_TEMP_. stores files into two locations: _DIR_VALID_ or _DIR_TEMP_.
_DIR_VALID_ contains objects which were found to be valid (current, _DIR_VALID_ contains objects which were found to be valid (current,
not revoked, not expired) during the previous validation run, the not revoked, not expired) during the previous validation run, the
_DIR_TEMP_ location contains files retrieved via RRDP or rsync which _DIR_TEMP_ location contains files retrieved via RRDP or rsync which
have not yet been validated, or were rejected by the validation have not yet been validated, or were rejected by the validation
process. process.
If the remote publication point is unreachable on both RRDP and If the remote publication point is unreachable on both RRDP and
rsync, no purported "new" manifest file will be stored in _DIR_TEMP_. rsync, no purported "new" manifest file will be stored in _DIR_TEMP_.
It is possible that the _DIR_VALID_ location contains a locally It is possible that the _DIR_VALID_ location contains a locally
cached version of the object from a previous validation run. cached version of the object from a previous validation run.
B.2. Stage: preprocessing of the manifests D.2. Stage: preprocessing of the manifests
Constructing the path and filename based on the _rpkiManifest_ of the Constructing the path and filename based on the _rpkiManifest_ of the
CA certificate, the RP attempts to open what purportedly are two CA certificate, the RP attempts to open what purportedly are two
